newsitem.title: LUXEMBOURG: UK's Brown backs France over stability pact.
newsitem.headline: UK's Brown backs France over stability pact.

text.p: Britain's Chancellor of the Exchequer Gordon Brown said on Monday that the French government was right to consult its parliament before deciding about the European Union's stability pact.

Asked about France's desire for a period of reflection to study the pact, Brown told Reuters Financial Television: "France wants to take time to make representations to the National Assembly and is right for them to do that first."

"It wants to present its proposals to the National Assembly and then the European Community," Brown said. Earlier on Monday, new French finance minister Dominique Strauss-Kahn said France was determined to see a single currency start in 1999 but added that he could not agree on a stability pact immediately.

He asked for time to study the framework which will impose fines on countries who fail to keep their budget deficits under control once a single European currency gets underway. It would take more than a week to do that, Strauss-Kahn said, casting doubt on the chances of reaching agreement by next week's Amsterdam summit, and sending Europe's markets into turmoil in the process.

Brown also said his jobs proposal had won support among EU finance ministers. "What I've found today is that there is general support for what I am proposing. "Jobs and growth should be at the centre of the EU agenda," he said. Brown circulated a paper on his plans to his EU counterparts on Sunday night. The finance ministers are meeting in Luxembourg for their monthly Ecofin.

The paper, which follows a letter sent to the ministers last week, laid out three major points for discussion -- job creation and employability, opportunities for small businesses and completing the EU single market.
